note:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Back Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ w/ T1DM, HTN, HLD, and lower back pain s/p L5/S1 
fusion on ___ who presents w/ back pain.  

Patient has a longstanding history of prolonged and 
progressively severe disorder of bilateral L5 radiculopathy, in 
the setting of L5-S1 lytic spondylolisthesis. In the past, he 
had an injection with Dr. ___ also Dr. ___, 
with excellent relief that was durable over a significant period 
of time. However, his pain became more severe this year and was 
refractory to epidural steroid injections. During the ___, he 
had new
imaging studies demonstrate an unstable listhesis at L5-S1 
related to bilateral pars lysis and also demonstrated very 
severe neural foraminal stenosis with compression of the exiting 
L5 nerve roots bilaterally. Dr. ___ the patient on ___ 
and consented the patient for a minimally invasive TLIF.  

He is s/p L5/S1 fusion on ___ with Dr ___ presents 
with persistent pain despite oral medications (diazepam, 
hydromorphone, and tylenol). The patient previously had right 
radiating pain which resolved after surgery, but over the past 3 
days, has developed left-sided buttock pain, worse with position
changes and with movement. It was better with rest. He went to 
the ___ yesterday and had a CT scan which did not show 
any change in the placement of his hardware, after which he was 
discharged without medications. Patient then called the 
orthopedic spine clinic this morning and asked for pain 
medications over the phone ut was told that if he was unable to 
have good pain control at home, he would require ___ evaluation. 
Thus he presented to the ___. 
 
He denies trauma, fever, chest pain, difficulty breathing, new 
numbness or weakness. Patient has baseline residual numbness of 
the right lower extremity since surgery. No perineal numbness, 
urinary or fecal incontinence.  

Of note, he does see pain medicine in ___ as an outpatient 
but has not seen them since his surgery. He follows on a PRN 
basis. 

In the ___:  
- Initial vital signs were notable for: T 97.7F, HR 81, BP
134/101, RR 16, O2 Sat 98% RA  
- Exam notable for:  
Intact rectal tone. Painful but stable gait unassisted. No 
midline TTP. The surgical site is well healed without erythema 
or purulence. Overall neurovascularly intact, no signs of cauda 
equina syndrome, with any radiation of pain to left buttock, 
sensation is intact all dermatomes, patient strength is intact 
and within all myotomes.  

- Labs were notable for:  
-- Chem panel: Na 138, K 4.3, Cl 104, CO2 22, BUN 21, Cr 1.2 
with
Glc 130  
-- CBC: WBC 7.9, Hgb 11.1, Plt 251  

- Studies performed include:  
-- XR Lumbar spine ___  
Stable appearance of posterior approach L5-S1 fusion with disc
spacer. No acute bony abnormality or significant change compared
to the prior study.  
-- PVR was 10cc  

- Patient was given: IV morphine 4mg, PO acetaminophen 1g, IV
zofran 4mg, and PO dilaudid 4mg  

- Consults:  
-- Orthopedics: Given the patient's lack of localizing symptoms 
I
think an MRI is not warranted at this time. Would not recommend
that the patient have pain medications for extended duration of
time as patient should receive a prescription for pain 
medication
on ___. Would recommend that the patient follow-up
with Dr. ___ in a sooner rather than later basis.  

Vitals on transfer: T 97.7, HR 98, BP 142/96, RR 20, O2 Sat 99%
RA  

Upon arrival to the floor, patient endorses the above history.
Continues to endorse left buttock pain. Has gotten to the point
where he finds it hard to sleep at night. 

 
Past Medical History:
Type 1 diabetes  
Erectile dysfunction  
Hyperlipidemia  
Hypertension  
Retinopathy  
LLE Radiculopathy 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father side with DM  
No hx of cancer  
Uncle MI in ___.

Brief Hospital Course:
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[ ] Chronic Pain - Increased frequency of his PO Dilaudid and 
dosage of his PO Gabapentin while in the hospital, consider 
downtitration as tolerated 

ACUTE ISSUES
============
# Lower back pain: 
# Longstanding bilateral L5 radiculopathy: 
# S/p L5-S1 spinal fusion with Dr. ___ on ___: 
Patient presented to the Emergency Department with severe low 
back pain refractory to his home medications. He had no symptoms 
or evidence of cord compression, cauda equina, or other 
neurological symptoms. He remained neurovascularly intact. He 
was admitted for pain control due to inadequate home regimen. 
Spinal X-Ray in the ___ was normal with no changes. His home 
regimen was Gabapentin ___, diazepam 5mg q8h PRN, 
dilaudid 2mg q8-12h prn, and methocarbamol 500mg q4-6h PRN. He 
previously took MS ___ SR 15mg q12h PRN, prescribed by 
orthopedic surgery, for a short period following his surgery. 
While in the hospital, he continued standing Tylenol 1g q8h, 
Methocarbamol 500mg q4h PRN, Diazepam 5mg q8h PRN, Dilaudid 4mg 
QID PRN, Gabapentin ___. He will be discharged on this 
same regimen, with close follow up with the Chronic Pain 
Service. He will also follow up shortly with his orthopedic 
surgeon. The orthopedics team has recommended continuing ___ as 
tolerated, and wearing the TSLO brace as needed for comfort, 
though not necessary. 

CHRONIC ISSUES: 
=============== 
# Anemia: 
Upon presentation, Hgb was found to be 11.1, down from 13.8 in 
___. Per iron studies, appears consistent with anemia of 
chronic disease. Given the significant time gap, this may be a 
new baseline Hgb level. 

# Type 1 diabetes: 
Mr. ___ has a history of T1D, complicated by microalbuminuria 
and neuropathy. He was diagnosed at age ___. He was previously 
seen by diabetes educator and endocrinologist at ___, but it 
is unclear if he still follows. Per reports, his diabetes is 
uncontrolled, secondary to noncompliance. Takes 76U Tresiba in 
the evening and Novolog with meals on a sliding scale. On 
admission, A1c 9.1%. While in the hospital, he was continued on 
home insulin regimen - Tresiba 76U every evening. He was also 
placed on a sliding scale with humalog, and dictated his 
additional insulin requirements with a phone application. 

# Hypertension 
Patient continued on home lisinopril 40mg daily and 
hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg daily. 

# Hyperlipidemia 
Patient continued home atorvastatin 80mg daily. 

# Lower extremity edema 
Patient continued home furosemide 20mg daily. 

This patient was prescribed, or continued on, an opioid pain 
medication at the time of discharge (please see the attached 
medication list for details). As part of our safe opioid 
prescribing process, all patients are provided with an opioid 
risks and treatment resource education sheet and encouraged to 
discuss this therapy with their outpatient providers to 
determine if opioid pain medication is still indicated.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 
It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?  
==========================  
- You were admitted to the hospital for severe back pain and 
shooting pain down your left leg. You notes that the pain was 
excruciating and poorly controlled, and that you were having 
difficulty sleeping. 

WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL?  
==============================  
- You were seen by the orthopedic surgeons, who recommended 
following up in clinic in one week, and wearing the spinal brace 
for comfort. You were also seen by the chronic pain service. 
They recommended slight modifications in your medication 
regimen, as well as close outpatient follow-up in clinic. 

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?  
================================  
- Please continue to take all of your medications as directed
- Please follow up with all the appointments scheduled with your 
doctor

___ you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!  
Your ___ Team  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
